head.title: Let There Be Light, But Less of It

hedline.hl1: Let There Be Light, But Less of It

abstract.p: Dark Sky Society founder Susan Harder letter on February 26 article contends there is nothing 'historic' about Fire Island Lighthouse's current beacon

block.p: There is nothing ''historic'' about the high-output light bulb in the Fire Island Lighthouse (''Lighthouse Beacon Will Not Be Replaced,'' In Brief, Feb. 26). High-intensity light bulbs are a recent invention and have caused tremendous environmental damage -- acknowledged by the federal Fish and Wildlife Service, resulting in better guidelines from the Coast Guard for effective lighthouse beacons.

There is nothing ''historic'' about the high-output light bulb in the Fire Island Lighthouse (''Lighthouse Beacon Will Not Be Replaced,'' In Brief, Feb. 26). High-intensity light bulbs are a recent invention and have caused tremendous environmental damage -- acknowledged by the federal Fish and Wildlife Service, resulting in better guidelines from the Coast Guard for effective lighthouse beacons.
The Fire Island Lighthouse Preservation Society should research what is ''historic.'' Historically, a Fresnel glass lens surrounded a flame, concentrating the light into a beacon.

Additionally, there is nothing ''historic'' about an excessively bright light source that results in additional air pollution (including carbon dioxide, sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide) from generating electricity, as well as large numbers of birds dead at the foot of the lighthouse from exhaustive circling, because they are inexplicably attracted to light.
The writer is founder of the Dark Sky Society.
